qas.question: When was United States v. LaMacchia contested?
At the time, what infringement could not be prosecuted under criminal copyright law?
What loophole did the ruling give rise to?
If there is no profit involved, what would happen to criminal charges of fraud?
When was United States v. LaMacchia not contested?
At the time, what infringement could be prosecuted under criminal copyright law?
What loophole didn't the ruling give rise to?
What loophole did the ruling kill?
If there is profit involved, what would happen to criminal charges of fraud?

context: United States v. LaMacchia 871 F.Supp. 535 (<a0_0><b4_0>1994<b4_0/><a0_0/>) was a case decided by the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts which ruled that, under the copyright and cybercrime laws effective at the time, committing copyright infringement for <a1_0><b5_0>non-commercial motives<b5_0/><a1_0/> could not be prosecuted under criminal copyright law. The ruling gave rise to what became known as the "<a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>LaMacchia Loophole<b6_0/><a2_0/>,<b7_0/>" wherein criminal charges of fraud or copyright infringement would be <a3_0><b8_0>dismissed<b8_0/><a3_0/> under current legal standards, so long as there was no profit motive involved.
